Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying the contribution of a new type of H-bond to protein stability

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proteins are linear chains of amino acids that fold into complex three-dimensional structures by virtue of a variety of intramolecular interactions involving both their main chain (i.e. backbone) atoms, as well as the different, individual amino acid side chain atoms. One very well characterized interaction in proteins that provides structural stability is the hydrogen bond (H-bond), which is a type of electrostatic interaction formed between protein backbone atoms that have opposite polarity and positioned in a structurally accessible manner. This project investigates the role of an additional and previously underappreciated type of stabilizing interaction in proteins, H-bonds between backbone atoms of sequentially adjacent amino acids. This project will use an experimental approach that relies on the use of carbon-deuterium (C-D) bonds to visualize specific protein vibrations to investigate energetic contribution of this type of H-bond in protein stability. The interactions that define a protein's folding, structure, and stability are all important factors in activity and function, thus research to identify and quantify novel types of interactions have the potential to impact basic research into all aspects of protein science. This project will provide education and training for graduate, undergraduate and high school students by involving them in every aspect of the project.

H-bonds formed between backbone N-H donor and CO acceptors have long been appreciated as dominant forces underlying protein structure and stability. However, many residues within proteins adopt conformations with phi and psi values of approximately ±90° and 0°, respectively, which are traditionally considered forbidden due to a steric clash between the amide nitrogen (Ni) and that of the following amino acid (Ni+1). This project will investigate the (Ni+1)-H---(Ni) interactions formed within these conformations which constitute a previously underappreciated type of H-bond. The objectives of this project is to focus specifically on determining the stabilization mediated by the (Ni+1)-H---(Ni) H-bonds in R67 DHFR. This project will compare the stability of the protein with its (Ni+)-H---(Ni) H-bonds intact with that of an isosteric CH2 analog [wherein one or more of th(Ni+1)-H---(Ni) H-bonds are disrupted]. In addition, model systems will be used to generate a calibration curve that will enable an interpretation of the shifts in IR spectra observed with the protein in terms of stabilization. Successful completion of the objectives will provide a convincing demonstration that (Ni+1-H)---(Ni) H-bonds are formed, and importantly, will provide a gauge of their contribution to protein stability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins are biological molecules responsible for much of the structure and work required in living organisms. Proteins are linear chains of amino acids that fold into complex three-dimensional structures by virtue of a variety of intermolecular interactions involving both their main chain (i.e. backbone) atoms, as well as the different, individual amino acid side chain atoms.  Understanding these interactions would improve our ability to manipulate protein activity as well as contribute to efforts to predict three-dimensional structure from amino acid sequences. One very well characterized interaction in proteins that provides structural stability is the hydrogen bond (H-bond), which is a type of electrostatic interaction formed between a backbone amide hydrogen donor and a structurally accessible carbonyl acceptor.  In this project, we investigated the role of an additional and previously underappreciated type of stabilizing interaction in proteins, H-bonds between backbone amide donor hydrogens (Ni+1-H) and sequentially adjacent amide acceptors (Ni). The experimental approach relied on the use of carbon-deuterium (C-D) bonds to visualize specific protein vibrations, a technique developed in the PI's laboratory.  In this technique, native C-H protein bonds are replaced with C-D bonds, a substitution that is non-perturbative, but which makes the bond detectable with infrared spectroscopy.  The project focused specifically on determining the stabilization mediated by the Ni+1-H---Ni H-bonds in R67 dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), a homotetrameric enzyme that catalyzes the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate using the reduced form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) as a cofactor.  We synthesized singly deuterated glycine residues and used solid-phase protein synthesis to incorporate these residues into R67 DHFR and thereby generate different deuterated variants. We then characterized the C-D absorptions of the R67 DHFR variants, and examined their contribution to protein stability. Quantum calculations were performed to provide a theoretical interpretation of the observed experimental absorptions. The results were interpreted in terms of factors that contribute to protein folding, structure, and stability, which are important for protein activity and function.  With the broad role of proteins in living organisms and the increasing number of protein-based therapeutics, work to improve our understanding of the basic forces that contribute to protein activity and function has broad importance.  Lastly, the project also provided multidisciplinary training in biochemistry, biophysics, and protein chemistry for undergraduate, graduate, and senior scientists.
